claim: If you travel to France and Denmark, you'll need to change dollars into euros and krone.

supporting.text: France uses the euro, and Denmark uses the krone, so changing dollars to these currencies is necessary for transactions.

attacks.text: France uses the euro, and Denmark uses the krone, so changing dollars to these currencies is necessary for transactions.
Many places in Denmark also accept euros, reducing the need to exchange dollars for krone.
Credit cards are widely accepted in both France and Denmark, eliminating the need for physical currency exchange.
Acceptance of euros in Denmark is limited to tourist areas, and exchange rates are unfavorable, making krone necessary for most transactions.
Foreign transaction fees and dynamic currency conversion costs on credit cards can make cash exchanges more economical.
Even in non-tourist areas, many businesses in Denmark accept euros due to the high volume of cross-border trade with Germany.
Some credit cards offer zero foreign transaction fees, making them a better option than cash exchanges.

supporting.text: Many businesses in France and Denmark accept credit cards, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.

attacks.text: Many businesses in France and Denmark accept credit cards, reducing the need for physical currency exchange.
Credit card transactions often incur foreign transaction fees, making cash exchanges more economical for frequent small purchases.
Rural areas and small businesses in France and Denmark may not accept credit cards, necessitating local currency.
Many credit cards offer no foreign transaction fees, mitigating the cost concern for card usage abroad.
Tourists primarily visit urban areas where card acceptance is nearly universal, reducing reliance on cash.
Even with no-fee cards, dynamic currency conversion scams at point-of-sale can lead to unfavorable exchange rates.
Some cultural experiences (e.g., markets, festivals) in cities still predominantly use cash, requiring local currency.

supporting.text: Denmark is part of the EU but has opted out of the euro, so travelers must exchange dollars for both euros (France) and krone (Denmark).

attacks.text: Denmark is part of the EU but has opted out of the euro, so travelers must exchange dollars for both euros (France) and krone (Denmark).
Many places in Denmark accept euros despite the official currency being krone, reducing the need for currency exchange.
Travelers can use credit cards with no foreign transaction fees, minimizing the need for physical currency exchange.
Acceptance of euros in Denmark is inconsistent, especially in rural areas, making currency exchange necessary for reliability.
Credit card usage may not cover all expenses, such as small vendors or public transport, requiring some local currency.
Even in rural areas, mobile payment solutions are becoming widespread, reducing dependency on cash transactions.

supporting.text: Some travelers may already hold euros or krone from previous trips, eliminating the need to exchange dollars.

attacks.text: Some travelers may already hold euros or krone from previous trips, eliminating the need to exchange dollars.
Many travelers do not keep leftover foreign currency from previous trips, making this scenario uncommon.
Exchange rates fluctuate, so even if travelers have leftover currency, it may not be enough for the current trip.
Studies show that a significant percentage of travelers do retain small amounts of foreign currency for future trips.
Travelers who frequently visit Europe are more likely to hold onto euros or krone, making the argument relevant for a subset of travelers.
Even with fluctuating exchange rates, having some local currency reduces the total amount needed to exchange, saving time and fees.
The retained amounts are often too small to be practically useful for a new trip, necessitating additional exchanges.
Frequent travelers represent a minority of all travelers, so the broader claim still holds for most people.

supporting.text: Currency exchange rates and fees may make it more economical to use alternative payment methods instead of exchanging dollars.

attacks.text: Currency exchange rates and fees may make it more economical to use alternative payment methods instead of exchanging dollars.
Alternative payment methods like credit cards often have hidden foreign transaction fees that can exceed exchange fees.
Many merchants in France and Denmark still prefer cash, making alternative payment methods less universally accepted.
Some premium credit cards offer zero foreign transaction fees, making them cost-effective compared to currency exchange.
Contactless payments and mobile wallets are widely accepted in France and Denmark, reducing the need for cash.
Premium credit cards often have high annual fees that offset the savings from zero foreign transaction fees.
Tourist-heavy areas may accept mobile payments, but rural areas in both countries still rely heavily on cash.

supporting.text: France and Denmark have distinct currencies, so travelers must exchange dollars for both to comply with local monetary systems.

attacks.text: France and Denmark have distinct currencies, so travelers must exchange dollars for both to comply with local monetary systems.
Many travelers use credit cards that automatically handle currency conversion, reducing the need to exchange physical dollars.
Denmark accepts euros in some tourist areas, so exchanging dollars into krone may not always be necessary.
Credit card transaction fees and foreign exchange rates can be unfavorable, making physical currency exchange more economical.
Relying on credit cards assumes widespread acceptance, which may not be true in rural areas or small businesses.
Using euros in Denmark is not officially supported and may result in poor exchange rates or refusal by merchants.
Some credit cards offer zero foreign transaction fees and competitive exchange rates, mitigating cost concerns.
Prepaid travel cards with locked-in exchange rates can provide a cost-effective alternative to both credit cards and cash exchange.
